div.verse: The Greek word "presbyter" literally means "elder" but functioned as a church leader or overseer in early Christian communities. This letter is from the church leader to my dear friend Gaius, whom I genuinely love.
Dear friend, I pray that you're doing well in every way and that your physical health matches the good health of your soul.
I was overjoyed when some fellow believers came and told me how faithfully you're living according to the truth.
Nothing makes me happier than hearing that my spiritual children are living according to the truth.

The Greek emphasizes showing faithful love through actions, particularly hospitality to traveling Christian workers. Dear friend, you're showing true faithfulness whenever you help fellow believers, especially those you don't even know.
They've told the whole church here about your love. Please continue helping them on their journey in a way that honors God.

"The Name" refers to Jesus Christ. Early Christians often used this shorthand, similar to how Jews avoided saying God's name directly. They left to serve Christ without accepting any support from non-believers.
So we should support people like this, becoming partners with them in spreading the truth.

Diotrephes appears to be a local church leader who was rejecting John's authority and refusing to welcome traveling missionaries. I wrote something to the church, but Diotrephes, who loves being in charge, won't accept our authority.

The Greek term means "bringing charges with evil words" - essentially making malicious accusations. So when I come, I'll call out what he's doing—spreading malicious rumors about us. Not satisfied with that, he refuses to welcome fellow believers himself and stops others who want to help them, even kicking them out of the church.
Dear friend, don't copy what's evil but copy what's good. People who do good show they belong to God, but people who do evil show they don't really know God.
Everyone speaks well of Demetrius—even the truth itself vouches for him. We also speak well of him, and you know our testimony is reliable.
I have much more to tell you, but I don't want to write it with pen and ink.
The Greek literally says "mouth to mouth," an idiom meaning face-to-face conversation. I hope to see you soon so we can talk face to face.

"Peace" translates the Greek "eirene," equivalent to the Hebrew "shalom"—meaning complete well-being, not just absence of conflict. May you have peace. Our friends here send their greetings. Please give our personal greetings to each of our friends there.
